data.title: 50 Songs That Define the Last 50 Years of LGBTQ+ Pride
data.meta_description: The stories after Stonewall, starring Frank Ocean, Tegan and Sara, Jobriath, Troye Sivan, Grace Jones, and more
data.text:
The Rainbow Is a Prism: The Many Facets of LGBTQ+ Pop Music History

By Jes Skolnik

LGBTQ+ people have always been at pop‚Äôs vanguard, as performers and audiences; the history of pop music is queer history. Blues originators like Ma Rainey and Bessie Smith, both openly bisexual, helped form the foundation of what would become R&B and rock‚Äòn‚Äôroll. In the 1920s and early ‚Äô30s, Prohibition‚Äôs end gave way to the ‚ÄúPansy Craze‚Äù: cabaret drag performances that brought gay nightlife to the masses and carried their aesthetics into mainstream musical theater. In the mid-‚Äô30s, at the edge of the Great Depression, moral backlash‚Äîsometimes disguised as economic conservatism but usually explicit in its bigotry‚Äîshut down many of these clubs and formally criminalized gay sex at a scale that had never before been seen. The closet door, which hadn‚Äôt even existed as we know it now, slammed shut.

This didn‚Äôt stop LGBTQ+ musicians from shaping American pop culture. Jazz can‚Äôt be imagined without the contributions of giants like Billy Strayhorn (of Duke Ellington‚Äôs band), who was openly gay, and, later, Cecil Taylor, who found that three-letter word was too limiting. Even in the prescriptive world of ‚Äô60s pop, where teen rebellion was anticipated and pre-packaged, there were artists like Lesley Gore and Dusty Springfield. In fact, Springfield was one of the first pop icons to come out to the public (as bisexual, in 1970)‚Äîand, notably, she covered Gore‚Äôs ‚ÄúYou Don‚Äôt Own Me,‚Äù as subversive a song as there ever was, on her debut album. The ‚Äô70s brought glam and disco, gender play, and explicitly queer nightlife back to the mainstream; we can‚Äôt forget that decade‚Äôs great gay pop icon, Elton John, and its great bisexual ones, David Bowie and Freddie Mercury. Despite its great appeal to many a very hetero man, many of punk‚Äôs early groundbreakers were LGBTQ+, from Pete Shelley of the Buzzcocks, who was never shy about his sexuality, to Darby Crash of the Germs, who was sadly closeted during his short life. Undergirded by punk‚Äôs jagged energy and the electric, over-the-top styles of glam and disco, new wave made space for unconventional queer personalities and for pop to address the AIDS crisis. And so it has evolved, with the late ‚Äô80s and early ‚Äô90s giving a particular showcase to lesbian and bisexual women in pop (Meshell Ndegeocello, Melissa Etheridge, k.d. lang, the Indigo Girls), all the way to today, a moment that young pop star Hayley Kiyoko teasingly refers to as ‚Äú#20gayteen.‚Äù

This Pride month, Pitchfork editors and contributors have assembled a list of 50 songs from the past 50 years, post-Stonewall riots, that speak to the impact of LGBTQ+ culture and perspectives on the mainstream. Most of the songs here are by LGBTQ+ artists, with a few exceptions we included because they were too notable not to; most of our critics who wrote these entries are LGBTQ+, as well. But this is not in any way meant to be a definitive list; the field is just too wide to narrow to 50 songs.

Instead, we‚Äôre trying to tell as many stories within this community as we can. Some of the ones I would have loved to tell, personally, didn‚Äôt make it‚Äîlike Gary Floyd of the Dicks, whom I‚Äôve written about before for Pitchfork, or the endlessly talented Dee Palmer of Jethro Tull, who, like me, is trans and intersex. We‚Äôve tried to get as big a range as possible, though, from classic chart-toppers to genre notables from hip-hop, punk, house, and so on‚Äîand we‚Äôve also gotten some wonderful musicians to reflect on their personal soundtracks, too.

Pride month itself has a number of meanings and uses: a party, a chance to reflect on our history and think about the challenges we have in the present and going forward, a reason to connect with others and think about how all of us view community, a fierce legacy of radicalism and liberatory praxis. There are millions of different ways to be LGBTQ+, after all. I hope you find something meaningful in this list‚Äîa history you might not have known, a song you loved that you‚Äôd forgotten about, a new favorite‚Äîand that you‚Äôre able to tap into the powerful well of emotions that pop can engender in us and let that push you on. Let‚Äôs get free.

Jes Skolnik is a writer, editor, and musician who splits their time between Chicago and New York. Their first gay kiss was in junior high, with someone wearing a matching flannel, while listening to Peter Murphy‚Äôs ‚ÄúDeep‚Äù on shared Sport Walkman headphones.

Listen to selections from this list on our Spotify playlist and Apple Music playlist.

Roberta Flack: ‚ÄúBallad of the Sad Young Men‚Äù (1969)

For decades, gay bars offered their male patrons one of few safe havens. But ‚ÄúBallad of the Sad Young Men‚Äù looks below that comforting surface to offer a view of the scene that‚Äôs both poignant and pained. The song wasn‚Äôt written with an exclusively gay audience in mind‚Äîthough the straight woman who wrote its lyrics, the beat poet Fran Landesman, surely knew of that world, and her words have resonated deeply with many gay people. With music by Tommy Wolf, the song was popularized by Anita O‚ÄôDay in 1962, and found its most knowing interpretation in the 1981 version by the openly gay jazz singer Mark Murphy.

Still, Roberta Flack offers the meatiest reading on her 1969 debut album, First Take. Proceeding through the arcs of its melody with granular attention, Flack finds weight in every word. And brilliant and brutal words they are: In Flack‚Äôs elegant reading, we linger over seven minutes with all the sad young men who pass their time ‚Äúdrinking up the night‚Äù and ‚Äúmissing all the stars,‚Äù as a ‚Äúgrimy moon‚Äù watches them grow old. Flack‚Äôs version culminates in a crescendo of Streisandian power, idealizing a gay bar ode that pierces the heart. ‚ÄìJim Farber

Listen: Roberta Flack, ‚ÄúBallad of the Sad Young Men‚Äù

The Kinks: ‚ÄúLola‚Äù (1970)

Initially among the most popular and influential British Invasion bands, the Kinks were refused work permits for four years by the American Federation of Musicians in 1965‚Äîwhich meant no U.S. tours and, after 1966‚Äôs ‚ÄúSunny Afternoon,‚Äù no U.S. hits. Most groups would‚Äôve pursued a comeback by writing about something universally accessible. True to contrarian form, leader Ray Davies gambled on what was then utterly forbidden love, and saved the Kinks‚Äô careers.

Deftly leading listeners along a gradual path of discovery, Davies sings from the perspective of a rube who finds himself falling for a trans woman who affirms his masculinity and helps him accept himself. Smarter still is the arrangement, an earthy roots-rock sing-along that accentuates the naturalness of what had only recently been decriminalized in the UK, and would still be illegal for decades in much of the U.S. While pioneering films of the era like The Killing of Sister George reflected the difficulty of British LGBTQ+ life, ‚ÄúLola‚Äù emphasizes its joys. That positivity marks it as the crucial awakening song of a new era: the first post-Stonewall smash. ‚ÄìBarry Walters

Listen: The Kinks, ‚ÄúLola‚Äù

Wendy Carlos: ‚ÄúMarch From a Clockwork Orange‚Äù (1971)

With the release of her hugely successful album Switched-On Bach, Wendy Carlos demonstrated that Moog synthesizers could be as expressive as a piano. Then, while reading Anthony Burgess‚Äô novel A Clockwork Orange, teenage protagonist Alex DeLarge‚Äôs passion for ‚Äúa bit of the old Ludwig Van‚Äù inspired her to begin composing music based on Beethoven‚Äôs Ninth Symphony, Fourth Movement. ‚ÄúMarch From a Clockwork Orange,‚Äù which appears in Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs infamous film adaptation, is a synthesized choral symphony in which a single voice is transformed by vocoder into an eerily rapturous electronic chorus of ‚ÄúOde to Joy.‚Äù A groundbreaking moment in the history of synthesized sound, the song is a classical symphony cracked open to reveal technological machinery, a marvel as queer as the titular clockwork orange.

In the late ‚Äô70s, Carlos changed her professional name and image in reflection of who she was; the media handled this badly, causing her to shy away from identifiers, but she became an inspiring figure to many queer people. Now her legacy continues on her own terms; her pioneering work remains an inspiration to the many women working in electronic music to this day. ‚ÄìLorena Cupcake

Listen: Wendy Carlos, ‚ÄúMarch From a Clockwork Orange‚Äù

Labi Siffre: ‚ÄúIt Must Be Love‚Äù (1971)

‚ÄúIt Must Be Love‚Äù is pure sweetness, a lovely pop gem about that rush of emotion in a young relationship. It manages, with its plangent chords, to feel real instead of syrupy‚Äîafter all, a new love feels amazing, but its power can also be so intense as to be frightening. The original was a hit in the UK, and its writer and performer, Labi Siffre‚Äîa jazz guitarist, singer-songwriter, and poet‚Äîwas a rarity in the 1970s pop pantheon, an out gay man born to a Nigerian father and a Barbadian-Belgian mother who refused to tamp down his advocacy against apartheid at a time when that was a severely unpopular view to have.

Though Siffre is not actively recording these days, many of his ‚Äô70s and ‚Äô80s hits have been covered or sampled by a wide variety of artists, from Olivia Newton-John to Kenny Rogers to Kanye West. (The two-tone ska band Madness even covered ‚ÄúIt Must Be Love,‚Äù scoring a hit both in the UK and the U.S.) Siffre continues to meditate on art, power, and politics in poetry and essays, still vitalized decades on. ‚ÄìJes Skolnik

Listen: Labi Siffre, ‚ÄúIt Must Be Love‚Äù

Fanny: ‚ÄúCharity Ball‚Äù (1971)

Initially billed as a ‚Äúnovelty act‚Äù‚Äîhow else, cynically, would one market an ‚Äúall-girl‚Äù band in the early ‚Äô70s?‚ÄîFanny proved to the doubters that they were (surprise!) a damn fine hard rock band with enough harmonies and hooks for pop chart appeal. (David Bowie was an enormous fan, as are Amy Ray from Indigo Girls, Bonnie Raitt, and Jill Sobule.) Led by the Filipina-American sisters June and Jean Millington, the group scored an early hit single with ‚ÄúCharity Ball,‚Äù from their second album of same name, a party-ready boogie-rocker with a swinging backbeat and a blistering guitar solo. It would still make for a perfect, swaggering drag king lip sync performance. Though three out of four members were lesbian or bi, Fanny wanted to be categorized as a lesbian or feminist band about as much as they wanted to be seen as novelties; what they wanted was to just play, to be given the same space and gravity as any of their ‚Äúall-boy‚Äù counterparts. ‚ÄìJes Skolnik

Listen: Fanny, ‚ÄúCharity Ball‚Äù

Listen: Madeline Davis, ‚ÄúStonewall Nation‚Äù

David Bowie: ‚ÄúStarman‚Äù (1972)

It really is impossible to exaggerate the importance of ‚ÄúStarman‚Äù to a generation of young, sexually-questioning British kids. When Bowie draped an arm around Mick Ronson in the summer of 1972, on the hugely popular music show ‚ÄúTop of the Pops,‚Äù a nation was outraged. But the indignation of parents would only help endear the otherworldly Bowie to their children. For the generation that would spawn the out-gay pop stars of the 1980s, Bowie‚Äôs outrageous campery and sexual androgyny was a revelation, and for many watching that Thursday evening, life would never be the same again.

Now, almost half a century after it happened, David Bowie‚Äôs admission in the British music press that ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gay, and always have been‚Äù seems like no big deal. And after Bowie himself retracted his statement, first becoming bisexual and then resolutely straight, it has been seen by supporters and critics alike as nothing more than an aberration. But for some‚Äîthe style-makers, the trendsetters, the icons of the ‚Äô80s and ‚Äô90s‚ÄîBowie‚Äôs fauxmosexuality opened up a whole new world, and his performance of ‚ÄúStarman‚Äù was a pivotal moment in the lives of a whole generation of British musicians. ‚ÄìDarryl Bullock

Listen: David Bowie, ‚ÄúStarman‚Äù

Lou Reed: ‚ÄúWalk on the Wild Side‚Äù (1972)

On his most indelible song, Lou Reed narrates New York‚Äôs 1970s queer scene with the cool eye of a documentarian. The former Velvet Underground frontman had worked with Andy Warhol in the late ‚Äô60s, and ‚ÄúWalk on the Wild Side‚Äù names several of the gay men and trans women who ran in the art icon‚Äôs inner circle. Actresses Holly Woodlawn, Candy Darling, and Jackie Curtis all appear in Reed‚Äôs archly delivered lyrics, having flocked to New York as the one place where they could embrace their femininity openly and be lauded for it.

Produced by David Bowie and Mick Ronson, ‚ÄúWalk on the Wild Side‚Äù plays like glam rock with its engine cut out, dropping the bombast for an easier, more casual feel. It‚Äôs as if Reed didn‚Äôt feel that his ‚Äúwild side‚Äù was so wild after all‚Äîto straight people, maybe, but not to him. He‚Äôd already incubated in the city‚Äôs queer underbelly, and he had enough affection for it to memorialize the era. Reed‚Äôs runaway hit was among the first pop tracks to celebrate trans women by name in the Billboard Hot 100, but he never sang it like he was making history. He just called it the way he saw it.

‚ÄìSasha Geffen

Listen: Lou Reed, ‚ÄúWalk on the Wild Side‚Äù

Jobriath: ‚ÄúI‚Äômaman‚Äù (1973)

While Bowie was touting his fauxmosexuality in the press, actor and musician Bruce Wayne Campbell was reinventing himself as Jobriath Boone, the space cowboy who was going to out-Ziggy our David and show the world what the ‚Äútrue fairy of rock‚Äù could do. Sadly, no one took him seriously, and although today Jobriath is recognized as an influence by Morrissey, XTC‚Äôs Andy Partridge, and many others, his importance‚Äîas the first out-gay rock singer to sign to a major label‚Äîis largely overlooked.

The swaggering pomposity of ‚ÄúI‚Äômaman,‚Äù a single from Jobriath‚Äôs eponymous debut album, is a fantastic example of his talents. It‚Äôs a slice of theatrically high-camp glam rock, in which he makes a pitch for acceptance while looking and sounding like an alien being, something that all LGBTQ+ people can relate to. Yet the press hated him, seeing him as little more than a Bowie clone, and before long, he was headed down the road to self-destruction. But watch his appearance on the late-night TV show ‚ÄúMidnight Special‚Äù (where he is introduced by a clearly confused Gladys Knight), and then compare it to Bowie‚Äôs later performances with Klaus Nomi. Who was leading whom?

‚ÄìDarryl Bullock

Listen: Jobriath, ‚ÄúI‚Äômaman‚Äù

Donna Summer: ‚ÄúI Feel Love‚Äù (1977)

The first time Nicky Siano played ‚ÄúI Feel Love‚Äù at the Gallery, New York‚Äôs most important disco club and queer-friendly space, the crowd ‚Äúexploded.‚Äù Ever since, the song‚Äôs legacy has had less to do with its creators and everything to do with the people who were dancing that night‚Äîand every other joyous dancefloor filled with brown, black, and queer bodies after.

In 1977, Donna Summer and producers Giorgio Moroder and Pete Bellotte were not the likeliest of LGBTQ+ allies, or even aware they‚Äôd kicked off a revolution. While the sleek disco Summer made with Moroder and Bellotte resonated with queer audiences‚Äîtheir self-possessed, proudly erotic songs just jived with the sexual revolution and the flowering of the gay public imagination‚Äînone of them were clubgoers. They weren‚Äôt there to see the bodies that writhed to ‚ÄúI Feel Love,‚Äù to its Moog-powered melody and cyborgian drumming. But queer crowds immediately knew it was special: It‚Äôs a song about loving your body and your desires, a powerful sentiment for people whose urges were once seen as deviant. Four decades later, that power over crowds is undiluted, as is the freedom and recognition in its every beat. ‚ÄìKevin Lozano

Listen: Donna Summer, ‚ÄúI Feel Love‚Äù

Gloria Gaynor: ‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù (1978)

‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù probably would‚Äôve become a gay anthem even without the specter of AIDS. It has an undeniable flair for the dramatic: After moving through that filigreed piano intro, you can imagine a lone spotlight shining on Gloria Gaynor as she drags the man dumb enough to break her heart and crawl back for more. It was released as disco‚Äôs wave was beginning to break, topping the Billboard charts a few months before the infamous Disco Demolition Night at Comiskey Park. Had the story ended there, it‚Äôd represent the last, best gasp of a culture beaten into temporary irrelevance by thinly-veiled racism and homophobia. (The out lesbian diva Alicia Bridges‚Äô ‚ÄúI Love the Nightlife‚Äù stands out as another hit from this time.)

A few years later, when a generation of queer people was ravaged by a disease dismissed as ‚Äúthe gay plague,‚Äù ‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù made for the perfect rallying cry. It burns with righteous indignation and celebrates resilience, qualities well-suited to a community that scrapped for recognition and banded together even as it was condemned and ignored as a matter of policy. (You can imagine the marginalized asking the same rhetorical questions Gaynor poses in the pre-chorus: ‚ÄúDid you think I‚Äôd crumble? Did you think I‚Äôd lay down and die?‚Äù) Even after decades of progress, many LGBTQ+ people are still made to grapple with daily assaults on their personhood. ‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù remains there for them, ready to galvanize in moments when asserting your basic humanity feels like an act of defiance. ‚ÄìJamieson Cox

Listen: Gloria Gaynor, ‚ÄúI Will Survive‚Äù

Sylvester: ‚ÄúYou Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)‚Äù (1978)

It‚Äôs still stunning, the sheer radicalness of Sylvester: an out-and-loud, gospel-singing, gender-nonconforming queen among queens who not only revolutionized disco in the late ‚Äô70s, but affirmed her identity so intensely that few people dared question it. This track from her second album, Step II, was originally written as a gospel song for the piano; it was then remixed and produced into perfection by Patrick Cowley, another disco pioneer lost to AIDS. His version married Sylvester‚Äôs take-you-to-church vocals with the synthesizer, then still considered a revolutionary instrument. Packed skyward with handclaps, tambourine shakes, and lazer synths, not only is ‚ÄúYou Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)‚Äù a stone-cold classic of the disco era, it‚Äôs a revelation of queer desire. When Sylvester sings, ‚ÄúI feel real when you want me‚Äù to her dancefloor paramour, it‚Äôs not just a simple admission of want. The song is about singing the praises of someone‚Äîwhoever, whatever they happen to be‚Äîwho make us feel good, seen, validated, and alive. ‚ÄìT. Cole Rachel

Listen: Sylvester, ‚ÄúYou Make Me Feel (Mighty Real)‚Äù

Queen: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Stop Me Now‚Äù (1978)

This shamelessly jaunty, piano-pumping karaoke killer wasn‚Äôt a big hit at first, by Queen standards. It hails from Queen‚Äôs also moderately popular Jazz, which inspired Rolling Stone‚Äôs most suspiciously scathing review ever. (Sample dis: ‚ÄúIndeed, Queen may be the first truly fascist rock band.‚Äù) The song‚Äôs wan initial reception may have had something to do with the genders of its love interests, which flip from male to female and back again to assert that frontman Freddie Mercury was bisexual‚Äîand it was released just days before the gay visionary Harvey Milk was assassinated.

But like Elton John‚Äôs originally neglected ‚ÄúTiny Dancer,‚Äù ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Stop Me Now‚Äù is today considered quintessential. It‚Äôs the giddy, fun-loving flipside to the forcefulness of ‚ÄúWe Are the Champions,‚Äù and though it similarly acknowledges outside resistance, it does so with a flick of the wrist from a shy guy still hiding behind the sybarite self he strutted onstage so legendarily. In the early ‚Äô80s, Mercury indulged that pleasure-seeker, and he prematurely and cruelly met his mortality. But this song, with its poignant and high-Fahrenheit fantasy of enjoyment without end, will live forever. ‚ÄìBarry Walters

Listen: Queen, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Stop Me Now‚Äù

Village People: ‚ÄúGo West‚Äù (1979)

Most music fans would be forgiven for dismissing the Village People as a disco novelty act‚Äîand they wouldn‚Äôt be completely wrong. After all, their relentlessly gaudy ‚ÄúYMCA‚Äù remains inescapable to this day, providing manufactured glee at everything from bar mitzvahs to baseball games. In hindsight, however, it‚Äôs amazing that such an openly, flamboyantly gay act was able to reach popularity at all in the late ‚Äô70s, let alone earn household-name status within months of their formation.

‚ÄúGo West,‚Äù the title track of the Village People‚Äôs fourth studio album, stands alone among the band‚Äôs most famous songs: It‚Äôs a passionate, lustful ode to queer community and spirit. Released a few years after the staunch conservative Anita Bryant launched her despicable ‚ÄúSave Our Children‚Äù campaign, which became the blueprint for the next 30 years of anti-LGBTQ+ politics, ‚ÄúGo West‚Äù imagined a utopia free of homophobia and discrimination. The rousing choral chants of ‚ÄúTogether!‚Äù‚Äîblasting over joyous horns and hi-hats‚Äîdon‚Äôt just describe a man and his lover, but all queer folk yearning to find their tribe and flourish in the sun. ‚ÄìCameron Cook

Listen: Village People, ‚ÄúGo West‚Äù

Loose Joints: ‚ÄúIs It All Over My Face (Female Vocal)‚Äù (1980)

The gay, avant-garde musical prodigy Arthur Russell, working with DJ Steve D‚ÄôAcquisto, hustled up money in 1979 from the disco label West End Records for an experimental studio project. Hoping to capture the propulsive energy of their favorite New York hotspot, the Loft, Russell and D‚ÄôAcquisto invited musicians and singers into the studio and subjected them to Buddhist-influenced improv and DIY recording practices. Thus, Loose Joints were born.

DJ genius Larry Levan kidnapped the master tapes, taking it upon himself to remix the record with his connoisseur nightclub crowd at the Paradise Garage in mind. Levan‚Äôs reworking of the track is a masterpiece of throbbing, risqu√©, suspenseful funk‚Äîan off-kilter confluence of electric keys, propulsive bass, sinewy drumming by Philadelphia‚Äôs John Ingram, and a blas√©, haughty Melvina Woods vocal (‚ÄúIs it all over my face?/You got me love dancing‚Äù). No song better captures the vibey, druggy, slightly dissociated erotics of downtown New York in its post-disco thrall. To this day, Russell, D‚ÄôAcquisto and Levan‚Äôs mutant baby remains a staple of black and Latino gay ballroom scenes. In fact, a limber dancer with loose joints is probably fiercely voguing to ‚ÄúIs It All Over My Face‚Äù as you read this. ‚ÄìJason King

Diana Ross: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Coming Out‚Äù (1980)

Disco appealed to pretty much everybody except the straight white dudes who ran the music industry; they got tired of gay/black/Latino club DJs calling the shots, just as disco‚Äôs reigning band Chic morphed into an equally fierce songwriting, production, and instrumental team. One night, their leader Nile Rodgers spotted three Diana Ross‚Äìimpersonating drag queens at GG‚Äôs Barnum Room, a Manhattan disco where transgender acrobats on trapezes flew over the dance floor. He had the ingenious idea to have Miss Ross herself sing a roof-raising LGBTQ+ anthem as a thank-you to all those queens for supporting her (and Chic, too).

This meant Rodgers‚Äîa revolutionary in designer duds‚Äîwas never upfront about the fact that ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Coming Out‚Äù was obviously about sexuality. Indeed, it‚Äôs also about being your truest self and throwing aside shame‚Äôs shackles. Ross rose to the occasion, turning in a triumphant performance as exacting as Chic‚Äôs sashaying accompaniment. But Motown hated the album, demanded the tapes, remixed them to downplay Chic‚Äôs instrumentation, and released diana in 1980 without so much as a single for the first month. Rodgers and collaborator Bernard Edwards nearly disowned what they‚Äôd originally considered their crowning achievement. Then ‚ÄúUpside Down‚Äù went No. 1, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Coming Out‚Äù hit No. 5, and *diana‚Äî*ultimately her biggest solo album ever‚Äîsold nine million internationally. Disco wasn‚Äôt dead yet; queers still had clout. ‚ÄìBarry Walters

Listen: Diana Ross, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Coming Out‚Äù

Soft Cell: ‚ÄúTainted Love‚Äù (1981)

When Ed Cobb wrote ‚ÄúTainted Love‚Äù in 1964, he never could have imagined its grim repurposing two decades later. In the ‚Äô80s, the song came to represent the fear and dread that gripped the gay community at the very start of the AIDS crisis. The soul singer Gloria Jones first recorded a manic version of the song in 1965, and in the early ‚Äô70s, it became a favorite of the U.K.‚Äôs Northern Soul scene. Then Soft Cell‚Äôs Marc Almond changed the piece radically in 1981 by taking a much slowed-down and sleazed-up approach, and it became an unlikely smash in the U.S.

At that time, AIDS had not yet been given that name, though gay men knew all too well of a mysterious new ‚Äúcancer‚Äù ravaging the community. The key lines in the song, ‚ÄúOnce I ran to you/Now I‚Äôll run from you,‚Äù were the first to capture the new terror surrounding sex and connection. At the same time, Soft Cell‚Äôs shadowy version embraced the darkness, capturing the complex amalgam of pitched attraction and deep angst that marked earlier eras of gay life. In 1985, when AIDS was overwhelming the community, ‚ÄúTainted Love‚Äù appeared once again, this time via the British group Coil. Their video for the song cast one of their own members as a man dying of the disease, finally putting the plague into full, savage focus. ‚ÄìJim Farber

Listen: Soft Cell, ‚ÄúTainted Love‚Äù

Grace Jones: ‚ÄúPull Up to the Bumper‚Äù (1981)

The subject matter of ‚ÄúPull Up to the Bumper‚Äù has been interpreted widely as anal sex, oral sex, and, well, simply parking a car. But therein lies the sly, transgressive power of Grace Jones: Between her cutting sense of humor and relish of outr√© spectacle, the Jamaican pop iconoclast has never been hemmed in by flimsy, pearl-clutching moral codes, even if those same codes most likely played a role in the song‚Äôs mainstream radio swift ban for its ‚Äúlewd content.‚Äù (It was released the year of Reagan‚Äôs inauguration, after all.)

Jones‚Äô genre-hopping artistry earned her a diehard LGBTQ+ fan base from day one, largely because of her very uncommon divadom. By gleefully toying with masculine and feminine conventions, she offered her queer audience a constantly evolving performance in which they could recognize their own sexual fluidity. ‚ÄúBumper‚Äù succinctly captures Jones‚Äô protean mix of playfulness and aggression, simultaneously tongue-in-cheek and dead serious. It‚Äôs a masterstroke of double entendre that, with its sinuous reggae-disco backdrop and Jones‚Äô snarled vehicular puns, really only demands one thing from you: that you move. ‚ÄìEric Torres

Listen: Grace Jones, ‚ÄúPull Up to the Bumper‚Äù

Pete Shelley: ‚ÄúHomosapien‚Äù (1981)

Pete Shelley shared private lusts to which the shame clung like incense on priestly robes. Embracing synthesizers just when everyone else in England did, the former Buzzcocks singer-guitarist coaxed out of them what everyone in England wasn‚Äôt: writing without a hint of code-switching about homo superiors in his interiors. The clinking-clanking ‚ÄúHomosapien‚Äù made an excellent solo debut for a songwriter whose previous works relied on the all-purpose second person pronoun yet whose prissy, epicene vocals, on desperation moves like ‚ÄúEver Fallen in Love (With Someone You Shouldn‚Äôtve‚Äù and ‚ÄúYou Say You Don‚Äôt Love Me,‚Äù gave the game away. This is a vignette by an orgasm addict, out and loving it, of understanding that life is as much performed as it is lived, of cruising for losers because it‚Äôs fun. Not as fun: the BBC banning it for its ‚Äúexplicit reference to gay sex.‚Äù Their loss. ‚ÄìAlfred Soto
